info.game_comments:
2009 Tournament of Champions quarterfinal game 4.
From Las Vegas.

(1, 1).clue: Si, President Wilson... I led the 1916 raid of a N.M. town but sending troops into Mexico after me?  Bad idea!

(2, 1).clue: Rolling Stone named this 1967 Beatles album the greatest of all time & deemed its cover a work of art

(3, 1).clue: These, from the state flower of Kansas, are a natural way to relieve insomnia

(4, 1).clue: Bill Clinton unseated this U.S. president
(4, 1).correct response: George H. W. Bush (George Herbert Walker Bush)

(5, 1).clue: This high South American lake straddles the border between Bolivia & Peru

(1, 2).clue: Monsieur Zola, merci beaucoup for writing "J'Accuse" pour moi, sorry it got you busted for libel

(2, 2).clue: Released in 1969, it's the musical tale of a "deaf, dumb & blind kid" who "sure plays a mean pinball"

(3, 2).clue: This super food, which even resembles the brain, has fatty acids that help with brain function

(4, 2).clue: In 1965 he defeated Philippine President Macapagal

(5, 2).clue: Entebbe is a key Ugandan port on this, the world's second-largest freshwater lake

(6, 2).clue: One who usually expects a favorable outcome

(1, 3).clue: Czarina, they'll have to poison, shoot, shoot again & drown me in the Neva River to tear us apart!  I'm feeling dizzy...

(2, 3).clue: Her "Pearl" album wasn't yet completed when she died in 1970

(3, 3).clue: At 70ish calories, this "incredible edible" packs a lot of protein & nutrients like choline, a memory booster

(4, 3).clue: Valery Giscard d'Estaing was beaten by him in a 1981 election

(5, 3).clue: Ownership of Lake of the Woods is split between these 2 countries

(1, 4).clue: It's April 14, 1865 & I'm having a bad night, too; I got stabbed in the throat but I'll stay on as Sec. of State

(2, 4).clue: This feast from Guns N' Roses is one of the biggest-selling debut albums of all time

(3, 4).clue: Squash & sweet potatoes are rich in this orange pigment that's good for the eyes & the brain

(4, 4).clue: In 1995 Aleksander Kwasniewski defeated this incumbent

(5, 4).clue: The reservoir known as Lake Nasser in Egypt is Lake Nubia in this country

(6, 4).clue: 5-letter term for apparent, as a lie

(1, 5).clue: Hey, "the Elder"! It's your nephew "the Younger" here, what did you think of my "Letters" to Emperor Trajan?

(2, 5).clue: Simon & Garfunkel were a "matching set", both dressed in black, on the cover of this 1968 album

(3, 5).clue: Treat yourself to this food, especially to the "dark" type which enhances mood & brain activity

(4, 5).clue: Leonid Kuchma ousted Leonid Kravchuk in this country

(5, 5).clue: In 1499 explorer Alonso de Ojeda followed the South American coast to this lake & named the region Venezuela

(6, 5).clue: 2-word French term for a small item of aesthetic interest

(1, 1).clue: This state capital is about 85 miles northeast of San Francisco

(2, 1).clue: In this 2008 film Jedi Knights try to restore peace as the droid army rampages

(3, 1).clue: Even with two extra pawns, white can't force a win here, because these pieces can travel only on opposite-colored squares

(4, 1).clue: Its name comes from geranos, Greek for "crane"; its seed capsules look like a crane's bill

(5, 1).clue: The Boathouse, this poet's writing shed in Laugharne, Wales, is now a museum

(6, 1).clue: This 4-syllable word can refer to any one of the 4 authors of the Gospels or to a type of minister

(1, 2).clue: Much of this nation's northern border with Saudi Arabia is undefined, as it lies in the desert

(2, 2).clue: 4 musicians help Lord Admiral save Pepperland from the Blue Meanies & their anti-music missiles in this classic

(3, 2).clue: Literally "in passing", it's the 2-word term for how a pawn can capture another pawn that's moved past it

(4, 2).clue: In 1907 a pink one of these boutonniere flowers was chosen as the emblem of Mother's Day

(5, 2).clue: In the early 14th century, he called his most famous work a "comedy" because of its sad beginning & happy ending

(6, 2).clue: The name of this, a meeting or conference, comes from the Greek for "to drink together"

(1, 3).clue: In a children's tale, this city of Germany is known for its band of animal musicians

(2, 3).clue: Mrs. Brisby gets help from some super-smart rats who've escaped from a lab in this Don Bluth film

(3, 3).clue: (Jon of the Clue Crew demonstrates with a chessboard.)  White should have an easy win here, but he blows it by moving his queen to the D6 square, leading to this drawn outcome

(4, 3).clue: Japan's special day honoring this flower is also called the Festival of Happiness

(5, 3).clue: His father came from Russian nobility; his mother was descended from an African prince

(6, 3).clue: A mere dabbler wouldn't know that this 10-letter Italian word means "a lover of the arts"

(1, 4).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew delivers the clue from the University of Wisconsin-Madison.)  Memorial Union Terrace at University of Wisconsin-Madison is right on this lake, whose name comes from a Siouan word

(2, 4).clue: 50-foot-tall, metal-eating, talking robot befriends boy in this 1999 film

(3, 4).clue: Initiated by the moves E4 E6, this defense got its name from its use by a Paris team in an 1834 match with London

(4, 4).clue: The genus of this purplish flower is also a musical instrument

(5, 4).clue: The Irish Literary Theatre opened on May 8, 1899 with this co-founder's drama "The Countess Cathleen"

(6, 4).clue: Similar to metonymy, it's a part standing in for the whole, like "sail" to mean a ship

(1, 5).clue: An Australian gold mining town shares this name with former Aussie prime minister Robert

(2, 5).clue: In this 2007 film things don't get better for young Marjane after the Shah is supplanted by the Islamic Revolution

(3, 5).clue: (Jon of the Clue Crew demonstrates with a chessboard.)  White can't move his knight, because doing so would expose his king; the knight's said to be stuck to the king with this tactic, named for a pointy little object

(4, 5).clue: Saffron is derived from this flower

(5, 5).clue: In 1871, as a debauched, visionary 16-year-old, he wrote "Le Bateau ivre" or "The Drunken Boat"

(6, 5).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew performs a science experiment with a purple Magic Marker.)  Draw on chalk & put it in water to see the component layers of marker color; it's a demonstration of this range of lab techniques that separate & analyze, from the Greek for "color" & "writing"

(0, 0).clue: Tennyson called this British painter, Constable's contemporary, the "Shakespeare of Landscape"
